work.title: Che si può fare?

composer.name: Barbara Strozzi
composer.longDescription: Barbara Strozzi was one of the most prolific female composers of the Baroque era. A singer, composer, and intellectual, she published eight volumes of vocal music, a remarkable achievement for any composer of the time, let alone a woman. Her works are known for their emotional depth, intimate expression, and daring harmonies.
composer.shortDescription: Baroque Venetian composer and singer, renowned for her emotionally charged solo vocal music.

work.shortDescription: A piercing Baroque solo lament transforming helplessness into defiant emotional clarity.
work.longDescription: Che si può fare? is a chamber cantata by Barbara Strozzi, published in 1664. Written for soprano and continuo, the work laments betrayal and abandonment but ultimately asserts emotional agency. Strozzi’s music stretches harmony and time, making sorrow audible and resistance palpable.
work.rawContent:
VOCAL · CHAMBER CANTATA

~6–8 MINUTES

Instrumentation Summary

Soprano & Continuo (typically Theorbo, Harpsichord, Viola da Gamba or Cello)

Mood and Style

Lamenting · Resilient · Intimate

insight: A piercing solo lament that transforms helplessness into power. Strozzi’s vocal line writhes with grief, but never yields. A defiant early cry for agency, it remains strikingly relevant in programs about resistance and emotional survival.

work.title: Three Songs

composer.name: Ruth Crawford Seeger
composer.longDescription: Ruth Crawford Seeger was a pioneering American modernist composer and the first woman to receive a Guggenheim Fellowship for composition. Her music pushed the boundaries of dissonance, rhythm, and structure, and she was a leading figure in both avant-garde and folk music circles.
composer.shortDescription: American modernist composer known for her radical harmonic language and political edge.

work.shortDescription: A dissonant, political vocal triptych that fuses early modernism with protest.
work.longDescription: Composed between 1930–32, these three songs by Ruth Crawford Seeger set Carl Sandburg’s poetry to urgent, angular music. Each song critiques aspects of American life and power structures with searing clarity, rendered in dissonant counterpoint and bold textures.
work.rawContent:
VOCAL · VOICE & CHAMBER ENSEMBLE

~8–10 MINUTES

Instrumentation Summary

Voice, Flute, Oboe, Clarinet, Bassoon, Piano, Strings

Mood and Style

Urgent · Dissonant · Political

insight: A rare example of early 20th-century protest music by a woman composer, these songs confront injustice with sharp dissonance and clear-eyed poetry. Their modernist sound world matches the social critique embedded in the text.

work.title: The Voice of Desire

composer.name: Judith Weir
composer.longDescription: Judith Weir is a leading British composer known for her clear, spare textures and psychologically rich vocal music. She often explores the intersection of personal emotion and broader political themes through chamber opera and song.
composer.shortDescription: British composer noted for lyrical, precise vocal music exploring psychological and political themes.

work.shortDescription: A lucid, intimate song cycle reflecting on desire, defiance, and emotional fracture.
work.longDescription: Composed in 2003, Judith Weir’s The Voice of Desire is a four-song cycle for soprano and chamber ensemble, setting texts by poets Judith Kazantzis, Eavan Boland, and Anne Stevenson. The music is introspective and lean, drawing power from subtle harmonic shifts and emotional restraint.
work.rawContent:
VOCAL · VOICE & CHAMBER ENSEMBLE

~12 MINUTES

Instrumentation Summary

Soprano, Oboe, Clarinet, Cello, Piano

Mood and Style

Introspective · Tense · Lyrical

insight: A song cycle that delves into emotional uncertainty, political tension, and the human cost of desire. Weir’s lucid style gives voice to poetry that resonates with personal and social unrest — a quiet revolution in chamber form.
